awd_titl_txt: High Resolution Chromatography for Lipids and Proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Robert Kennedy and his group at the University of Michigan are working to improve the characterization of complex mixtures such as blood and soil extracts, common in nature and industrial processes. Studying the composition of such mixtures is vital to biology, chemistry, environmental science, and production of valuable chemicals. A powerful approach to analyzing such mixtures begins by separating chemical components from one another by passing the mixture through a chromatographic column packed with small particles ("stationary phase") that interact to varying degrees with different components. As chemical components emerge from the column they are analyzed by a device called a "mass spectrometer" for identification and quantification. The ability to separate mixture components can be improved by using smaller particles and longer columns, but such changes require higher pressure to drive the sample through the column. Current technology is largely limited to operating at pressures below 20,000 psi. As a result, many mixtures cannot be properly analyzed. The Kennedy group is working to relieve this constraint by developing chromatographic systems that can operate at up to 100,000 psi. The improved chromatography will allow better characterization of mixtures in many disciplines. For example, the group is using the new methods to identify biomolecular patterns (primarily lipids and proteins) associated with microbes capable of efficient biofuel production.  Efforts to disseminate knowledge about the important methods, principles, and applications include involvement of undergraduate students and outreach to even younger students, including members of underrepresented groups.

Analytical separations are critical to complex mixture analysis. High-pressure liquid chromatography (HPLC) is a dominant method for separations.  To analyze many complex mixtures, it is necessary to achieve higher resolution than what is currently possible.  The Kennedy group is developing next-generation, high-resolution separations for chemical analysis. They are advancing ultra-high pressure liquid chromatography (UHPLC) through development of a) fittings that can be routinely used up to 100 kpsi; b) packing conditions for small particles (0.5 to 1.7 um) in long columns; and c) packing conditions for different modes of LC, such as hydrophilic interaction chromatography (HILIC) and ion-exchange (IEX), in long columns. They are also coupling their new UHPLC columns with other separation methods in two-dimensional (2D) separations coupled to mass spectrometry (MS). They are targeting unprecedented peak capacity (10,000) by 2D chromatography of lipids and intact proteins, with the expectation that increasing peak capacity will result in detection of more compounds in complex samples with better sensitivity and reproducibility. In a specific application, they are probing the lipidome and proteome rearrangements in bacteria that develop resistance to toxicity of fuel products. Identification of such rearrangements is crucial for engineering bacteria for high-yield biofuel production.   The work is being made broadly available through interactions with collaborators at the National High Magnetic Field Laboratory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Complex mixtures consisting of hundreds to hundreds of thousands of chemicals are routinely encountered in basic and applied research, e.g. in biological fluids, environmental samples, and industrial processes. Analysis of such mixtures, which is vital for increased understanding of the systems involved, usually requires a method of separating or fractionating the components. Liquid chromatography is the most commonly used method for such studies. Current practice of high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) uses 1.7 to 3.0 um particles as a stationary phase with column lengths of 5 to 25 cm. These columns have peak capacity, that is the maximum number of resolved components, of ~200. Theory suggests that smaller particles and longer columns would improve peak capacity; however, such changes increase the pressure requirements for flowing mobile phase through the columns. We have helped develop a system that can operate at 35,000 to 50,000 psi, compared to 15,000-20,000 psi for the best commercially available systems. We have also developed conditions for preparing columns that are 50-100 cm long packed with 1.1 to 1.7 um particles. Further we have extended the types of columns from reversed phase, commonly used for peptides, lipids, and non-polar molecules, to hydrophilic inteteraction liquid chromatography (HILIC) which is useful for polar molecules such as metabolites. These columns can reach a peak capacity of 1,000 in a 4 h separation time or 375 in a 15 min analysis time. These columns were demonstrated for high resolution analysis of plasma lipid extracts and metaolite extracts. In summary, this work demonstrated substantial advances in our ability to analyze complex mixtures.

As part of the project we also took on a new challenge of analyzing RNA. RNA has long been known to be critical for making protein from the DNA genetic code, but it is also emerging to be important in regulating a variety of cellular processes and as a valuable new drug modality. Study of RNA has revealed that the 4 bases are frequently modified and further that these modifications are important in altering the function. Approximatly 150 different types of modifications are known. We developed: 1) methods to quantify the different modifications in RNA; 2) sequence RNA including with modifications; 3) demonstrated that these methods could be used to detect how environment altered the modification landscape of RNA, e.g. following heat or oxidative treatment of yeast. These advances set the stage for further study of RNA and its modifications in a variety of health and technical endeavors.

While the tools developed in this project are of interest for fundamental analytical chemistry, the importance of analyzing complex mixtures means that the potential for impact goes to any field that requires such analysis. Tis includes fundamental biology, environment, drug development, and polymer development. 

Further, the project providing training separations analysis for five graduate students. Those that have graduated are employed in the pharmaceutical industry or environmental agencies due to the high demand for advanced separation methods.


Last Modified: 09/26/2024
Modified by: Robert T Kennedy
